title: reference request - Multivariable polynomial interpolation via evaluations from entrywise powers of a point
body: I am interested in multivariate polynomial interpolation. Within computational complexity theory, I use it to create efficient reductions between counting problems. In the univariate case, there is a useful characterization of when such polynomials of degree $d$ can be interpolated: $d+1$ distinct evaluation points (since the coefficient matrix of the corresponding linear system is Vandermonde ). In the multivariate case, it is my understanding that a similarly useful characterization is not known. However, I often encounter the following special case (for which I hope more is known). For $n \ge 3$ , let $$p \in \mathbb{C}[X_1, X_2, \dotsc, X_n]$$ be a homogeneous polynomial of (total) degree $d \ge 1$ , which has $N = \binom{d+n-1}{n-1}$ coefficients. Given a point $$x = (x_1, x_2, \dotsc, x_n) \in \mathbb{C}^n,$$ consider the set of points $$S = \left\{\left(x_1^k, x_2^k, \dotsc, x_n^k\right) \in \mathbb{C}^n~\middle|~0 \le k \le N - 1\right\}$$ defined by taking entrywise (aka Hadamard or Schur) powers of $x$ . Given the evaluations of $p$ at all the points in $S$ , we have a linear system whose coefficient matrix is Vandermonde (which follows from the definition of $S$ ). We can interpolate $p$ iff this matrix is invertible iff the monomials of $p(x) = p(x_1, x_2, \dotsc, x_n)$ are distinct. For $n=2$ , these monomials are distinct iff the points in $S$ (when viewed as length-two vectors) are pairwise linearly independent iff neither $x_1$ nor $x_2$ is $0$ and the ratio $x_1 / x_2$ is not a root of unity. This is a useful characterization. Question What about a useful characterization when $n > 2$ ? For any $n \ge 3$ , is there a useful characterization of $x$ with the property that, for all degrees $d \ge 1$ and all homogeneous polynomials $p$ of (total) degree $d$ , the monomials of $p(x)$ are distinct? reference-request polynomials Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jun 15, 2020 at 7:27 Community Bot 1 2 2 silver badges 3 3 bronze badges asked May 28, 2015 at 18:34 Tyson Williams 563 3 3 silver badges 17 17 bronze badges $\endgroup$ Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
